[32y/o, white male] -- I live with my parents, who have no idea how bad my depression is. They think my room is messy because I'm lazy but in reality I just don't have the strength to clean it. I also suffer with sensory issues which makes cleaning harder. My room isn't even messy anymore; it's filthy.
I mostly struggle with managing my bin, which has resulted in a rat infestation in my room. My parents don't know and I'm scared to tell them in case they get mad. But I don't know how to fix it on my own, especially since I don't do well with things like that.
Unfortunately, I need to get my room clean in a week and I just don't know what to do. I've always struggled with cleaning but my depression has made everything so much harder, so I'm very worried that it won't get done in time. 
Any advice would be greatly appreciated. Thank you

Update: Thank you so much for all of your advice. I’m happy to report that although my room isn’t spotless, it’s clean and liveable. Thank you for all of your advice and kind words
column2:

Have you tried reaching out to a mental health professional who could provide you some coping strategies for your depression? They may even be able to suggest small, manageable steps to help you start with the cleaning process. 

As for dealing with the rat infestation, perhaps it would be helpful to look for a pest control company who may be able to safely and discretely deal with the problem. And remember, it's okay to ask for help. Your parents might be more understanding than you think.

Remember, it's okay to do a little each day. You don't need to tackle it all at once. Take a few minutes each day to get rid of a bit of the mess. Keep a small bag by your side and fill it up bit by bit. It may feel too slow, but progress is progress. 

Please remember, you're not alone in this. There are support systems out there for situations just like yours. You're already doing great by reaching out and asking for advice, so give yourself some credit. Remember, it's okay not to be okay. Keep going, one tiny step at a time. 

I’m glad to hear that your room is better now. You’ve taken the first step, remember this journey is continuous. Don't beat yourself up if some days seem harder than others. Persistence is key. Keep moving forward and celebrate the progress you've made.

I'm really sorry to hear that you're going through this. Dealing with mental health issues is tough, but you're not alone and it sounds like you're coping with an awful lot right now. It's important to remember that mental health is as important as physical health, and it's okay to ask for help when you need it.

First things first, you may want to consider talking to your parents about what you're going through. From your post, it sounds like they're unaware of the magnitude of your struggles. They might be more understanding and supportive than you think, especially if they learn about your depression and daily challenges.

For cleaning your room, I understand that it can be a daunting task, especially when you're not feeling your best. Maybe try breaking the task down into manageable portions, it can be less overwhelming this way. You don't necessarily have to get it all done in one day. Start with the most pressing issue, the rats. 

There are services that can come and help deal with an infestation. If you're unable to do that yourself or to afford such a service, perhaps you could ask someone you trust for help with this? After all, it's quite a specialized task.

Dealing with the trash can be broken down in a similar way. Maybe don't think about it as a large task, but instead as a series of smaller tasks. First, pick up any garbage that's lying around and get it into bags. Then, take one bag out at a time to the bin. 

Remember, it's okay to ask for help with this. Whether it be a friend, a family member or a mental health or cleaning professional, it's important that you don't feel you have to deal with everything on your own.

Lastly, if you are not currently seeking help for your depression, I would strongly advise contacting a healthcare professional who can guide you. There are also lots of great resources and hotlines, where you can speak to mental health professionals who can provide you with guidance and support.

Stay strong, and remember that it's okay to take things one step at a time. You're doing the best you can, and that's more than enough. All the best.

[32y/o, white male] -- "My dad just died and my mom wants me to hang out with her all the time. I''ve never liked doing casual things with her, and I'm very independent.

I don't know how to tell her to leave me alone. The best relationship we ever had was when I lived in another state. I moved back because of my dad, but now he's gone. 

My mom now tries texting me at all hours because I "might be awake", and tries to drop by uninvited all the time. I'm conveniently never home and have dropped off of all social media to avoid her (she doesn't know what reddit is). 

Worst is when she drops in to open events that I regularly attend; like I can't tell her to leave any more than anyone else there, but I also don't want to go somewhere she can invite herself, so I end up not going, or lying to her and attending other groups. 

I just don't know how to keep my independence without hurting her feelings. I get that she's lonely, but I don't want to be her go-to person. 

Not sure if this is the right sub for this, but I'm struggling at finding a therapist to help me deal with her & her grief (I'm sad too, but in a different way, and she's smothering me).
column2:
Firstly, I would like to express my condolences for your loss. It's definitely a challenging situation. 

Managing boundaries is tough, especially when it involves family. Continue honoring your independence and validate your feelings - it's okay to need space, even when grieving. Your feelings matter just as much as anyone else's. 

It might be helpful to communicate your needs to your mother. Although it may be difficult, a direct conversation about your struggle might serve as the first step. If confrontation isn't your preference, consider writing a heartfelt letter explaining your feelings and outlining your needs. Emphasize that while you care for her deeply and understand her loneliness, you also need space to process your own grief.

Group grief therapy might be helpful for both of you. A trained counselor can provide you with the tools needed to navigate through this journey. Additionally, your mom may meet others experiencing similar feelings of loneliness, which can help provide her with social support and alleviate her overreliance on you.

Overall, remember to be patient. This is new territory for both of you and navigating through it may take some time. There may be bumps along the way, but things will get better. 

Remember, it's okay to prioritize your mental health. You are not alone, and it's okay to ask for help.

Take a deep breath and step back - your pain, your mother's pain, and the situation itself, they're all valid. Your concern for your mom's feelings despite your own discomfort shows deep empathy. Most importantly, look after your own mental health. Make it a priority in your daily routine. This could be as simple as enjoying some quiet time, reading a book, a walk in the park or doing something you love.

Remember: it's okay to put your well-being first. You don't need to always be the pillar of strength for others, especially when you're going through a rough time yourself. So take each day one step at a time, and be patient with yourself.

Stay strong, and feel free to reach out if you're feeling overwhelmed or just need to talk. We're all in this together.

Respect for personal boundaries and our relationships with parents as adults can be complex, and it's natural for shifts in interaction to occur, particularly after a life-changing event such as this.

column1: [32y/o, white male] -- I don't know when exactly it started. Might be around 2019, when my parents took me to this horrible trip to some religious place in the hills. My problem is that I'm anxious before the trip happens and during it I'm completely fine. It's gotten better now tho, but not completely cured. Going alone or with friends seems like a mammoth task. Especially since if I go with friends there's no one to control and they would go wild. I know I need to get over this for the future. Any tips?
column2:
Hi there,

It sounds like you're dealing with anticipatory anxiety, where the thought of travelling is causing you more distress than the actual event. It's great that you're aware of the problem and want to work on it. Here are a few techniques that might help:

1. Mindfulness and Breathing: Practice mindfulness and deep breathing exercises to keep yourself grounded in the present moment. This can help control anxiety that comes from worrying about future events.

2. Cognitive Behavioural Therapy (CBT): Consider reaching out to a mental health professional who specializes in CBT. They can guide you through techniques to change your thought patterns and help you react differently to stress triggers.

3. Progressive Desensitization: Start with smaller trips close to home and gradually increase the distance over time. This therapy can help slowly desensitize you to the idea of travelling.

4. Journaling: Write out your thoughts, fears and anxieties about an upcoming trip. This might help you identify specific triggers or patterns.

Remember it's okay to feel anxious, everyone experiences it in different ways. You're already on the right path by seeking help and wanting to improve, so keep pushing forward. 

Lastly, if going with friends makes you uncomfortable, consider finding a travel companion who understands your anxiety and can help you cope with it during the trip. Try not to rush the healing process, it's often a gradual journey, and that's okay. Take care of yourself! 

Best of Luck!

Try getting out more often in your home city or nearby towns to gradually build up your confidence traveling alone or with friends. Small steps will eventually make bigger trips more manageable.

You mentioned an instance when you went on a trip while having online classes and felt a lot of pressure. Perhaps ensuring you have a clear schedule, with no assignments or exams close by, could make the travel experience more relaxing and enjoyable.

In addition, practicing stress-relief techniques such as meditation, deep breathing exercises or light physical activities could be beneficial.

You're already making progress since you've noticed things have gotten better with time. Be patient with yourself, it’s okay to feel uncomfortable and anxious, the key is not to let it stop you from enjoying your life and the experiences it brings. You've got this!

[32y/o, white male] -- I have no friends aside from one from primary school who I infrequently catch up with. I really just find most people not to be worth talking to, as I find it hard to connect with many people due to my lack of shared interests and my social anxiety.

However, I often feel lonely and kinda sad especially when I see people who are having a good time with their friends.

I did actually have a weird experience making a friend just recently though, but he's way older than me so it's a bit weird to hang out in person. I noticed he had an interest in something I really liked, and we had this great chat for about 10 minutes. It flowed so smoothly, and it was super passionate. We still message each other every couple of days.

Can anyone else relate to this?
column2:
Hey there! It absolutely sounds like what you're experiencing is something many people go through, especially with the condition of social anxiety making it hard to connect with people traditionally. 

Don't worry about age — if you feel a genuine connection with someone, their age shouldn't be a barrier to exploring that connection, unless it's genuinely affecting you negatively. 

Social media and the internet have made it much easier for us to connect with like-minded individuals. There are numerous forums and groups dedicated to all sorts of interests where you could find people who share your passion. 

It's understandable to feel lonely while seeing others having a good time. That said, remember that what is depicted on social media isn't always an accurate reflection of reality. It's a highlights reel, often devoid of the behind-the-scenes struggles.

Consider looking into meetups, clubs, or groups that feature your interests. If you feel safe and ready, therapy may also be something to consider as it could help you work through your social anxiety.

Remember, everyone's social life develops differently and at their own pace. You're not alone in this, despite it occasionally feeling that way.
